metadata.titleEn: Basic meteorological data of Sejila peak at Southeast Tibet station of Chinese Academy of Sciences (2020-2021)
metadata.description:
This data is the data of automatic weather station (AWS, Campbell company) set up at the top of the mountain in the west slope of Sejila by the comprehensive observation and research station of Southeast Tibet alpine environment of Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2016. The geographical coordinates are 29.5919 n, 94.6102 e, with an altitude of 4640 m, and the underlying surface is alpine grassland.
The data include daily arithmetic mean data of air temperature (℃), relative humidity (%), wind speed (M / s) and air pressure (MB) and daily accumulated value of precipitation. The original data is an average of 30 minutes before October 2018, and an average of 10 minutes after that. The temperature and humidity are measured by hmp155a temperature and humidity probe. The rainfall instrument model is rg3-m, the atmospheric pressure sensor probe is ptb210, and the wind speed sensor is 05103. These probes are 2 m above the ground. In terms of data quality: the obvious abnormal values are eliminated, the battery is damaged due to snow in the first half of 2019, and the data is missing. The missing temperature data is corrected by using the temperature fitting regression of 43900 m at nearby stations, and the data is yellow. Please pay attention when using it; the monitoring of precipitation starts from August 2019. The data station is a high altitude meteorological station in Southeast Tibet, which will be updated from time to time. It can be used by scientific researchers studying ecology, climate, hydrology, glaciers, etc.

background: In mountainous areas, different altitudes exhibit distinct vertical zones due to variations in water (precipitation) and heat (temperature) components, forming typical mountain vertical belts. The Sejila Mountain in southeastern Tibet has obvious characteristics of mountain vertical belts: from the foot of the mountain to the summit, there are broadleaf forests, mixed coniferous and broadleaf forests, coniferous forests, shrubs, and moss. The vegetation types in Sejila Mountain are rich, and the longevity of trees is notable (Lu et al., 2015). The tree line at 4390 m is one of the highest forest tree lines in the world, making it a hotspot for tree-ring and forest ecology research (Wang et al., 2014; Liang et al., 2016; Shen et al., 2018). Currently, there is limited research on the vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation in Sejila Mountain (Liang et al., 2011). Most studies by some scholars on the changes in temperature and precipitation vertical gradients in this region and its vicinity are based on the Baji Station (formerly Linzhi Station) and the nearby Bomi Station, focusing on the vertical temperature lapse rate across the entire Tibetan Plateau (Jiang Jingchao et al., 2016; Guo et al., 2016; Li et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2001, 2018; Zhang et al., 2018) and precipitation gradients (Guo et al., 2016).
research objective: Therefore, this article explores the vertical variation patterns of temperature and precipitation on the eastern and western slopes of the Sejila Mountain based on temperature and precipitation data from 11 meteorological stations. This not only deepens the understanding of the influence of slope orientation on the vertical gradient changes of temperature and precipitation in Sejila Mountain but also helps to better understand the physiological and ecological characteristics of plant and animal distribution with altitude changes. Additionally, it provides reliable data support for future hydrological modeling in this region.
challenges: Due to the many factors affecting the vertical temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient, among the meteorological stations in the Sejila Mountains, except for the mountain pass station, tree line station, and ecological station located on the ridge, all other stations are situated in valley areas. Additionally, the western slope and high-altitude stations are relatively few, which may affect the accuracy of the temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient obtained in this study.
methods: The data for this study includes daily temperature and precipitation records (from April to October) from 2013 to 2018 provided by the Linzhi Meteorological Bureau of the Tibet Autonomous Region for nine stations: Bayi, Niche, Station 114, Station 113, Shankou, Ecological Station, Rulang, Bingzhan, and Layue, as well as the main station of Southeast Tibet Station (shown in Figure 1 and Table 1) and two stations at the tree line. Based on the geographical locations of these stations, the stations in the Sejila Mountain area are divided into two natural geographical units according to slope orientation: the west slope (south slope) and the east slope (north slope). The temperature vertical lapse rate and precipitation gradient are estimated, with the Sejila Mountain Pass station belonging to both the west and east slopes. The estimation of the temperature vertical lapse rate and precipitation gradient is obtained through regression analysis based on the elevation of the stations and the temperature or precipitation amounts.
dataset: The data for this study includes daily temperature and precipitation values (from April to October) from 2013 to 2018 provided by the Linzhi Meteorological Bureau of the Tibet Autonomous Region for nine stations: Bayi, Niche, Station 114, Station 113, Shankou, Ecological Station, Rulang, Bing Station, and Layue, as well as the main station of Southeast Tibet Station (shown in Figure 1 and Table 1) and two stations at the tree line.
findings: From 2013 to 2018, the average temperature lapse rate (λ) at 11 stations on the Selila Mountain ranged from 0.59 to 0.63 °C·(100 m)^-1, with the lowest λ value in 2016 and the highest in 2014. The average λ from 2013 to 2018 was 0.60 °C·(100 m)^-1. The western slope had λ values ranging from 0.69 to 0.72 °C·(100 m)^-1, with the lowest λ in 2016 and the highest in 2014, and the average λ from 2013 to 2018 was 0.71 °C·(100 m)^-1. The eastern slope had λ values between 0.53 and 0.55 °C·(100 m)^-1. Unlike the Selila Mountain and the western slope, the lowest λ in the eastern slope occurred in 2015, while the highest was in 2017, with an average λ of 0.55 °C·(100 m)^-1 from 2013 to 2018. From 2013 to 2018, the average precipitation gradient on the eastern slope was 10.5 mm·(100 m)^-1, with the monsoon period showing a trend of first increasing, then decreasing, and then increasing again with elevation; during the non-monsoon period, the trend changed to first decreasing and then increasing, with a significant precipitation gradient above the southeastern Tibetan region.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how meteorological data is collected at high-altitude stations like the one on Sejila Mountain?
Example.Answer: Meteorological data at high-altitude stations such as the one on Sejila Mountain is collected using an automatic weather station (AWS) with sensors placed 2 meters above the ground to measure temperature, humidity, wind speed, and atmospheric pressure. The data is recorded at intervals of 10 minutes for temperature and humidity using an HMP155A sensor, wind speed using a 05103 sensor, atmospheric pressure using a PTB210 sensor, and precipitation using an RG3-M instrument.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a challenge faced when collecting meteorological data in mountainous regions?
Example.Answer: One challenge in collecting meteorological data in mountainous regions is the potential discrepancy in precipitation data during the winter and spring seasons due to limitations of the monitoring instruments. Additionally, variations in the vertical lapse rate of temperature and precipitation gradients can be influenced by the location of the stations, such as those situated in valleys versus those on ridges.

Example.Question: Can you illustrate an example of how datasets from multiple meteorological stations are used to study climate gradients in mountain ranges?
Example.Answer: An example of using datasets from multiple meteorological stations to study climate gradients is the analysis of temperature and precipitation data from 11 meteorological stations on the eastern and western slopes of Sejila Mountain. This involves regression analysis of altitude against temperature or precipitation to estimate vertical lapse rates and gradients, helping researchers understand the physiological and ecological characteristics of vegetation distribution and providing reliable data for hydrological modeling.

Definition.Question: What is meant by '气温垂直递减率' in the context of meteorological data collection?
Definition.Answer: In the context of meteorological data collection, '气温垂直递减率' refers to the rate of decrease in temperature with elevation. It is calculated by analyzing the relationship between the elevation of various meteorological stations and their recorded temperatures, often expressed in degrees Celsius per 100 meters.

Definition.Question: How is '降水梯度' defined when studying precipitation patterns in mountainous regions?
Definition.Answer: '降水梯度' in the study of precipitation patterns refers to the change in precipitation amount with elevation. This gradient is determined through regression analysis of precipitation data collected from stations at different altitudes, providing insight into how precipitation varies with elevation, especially during different seasons such as monsoon and non-monsoon periods.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for meteorological data at different altitudes in mountain regions compare to those used in other geographical settings?
Comparison.Answer: In mountain regions like the study area, data collection methods involve using sensors such as HMP155A for temperature and humidity, RG3-M for rainfall, PTB210 for atmospheric pressure, and 05103 for wind speed, mounted on an automatic weather station at high altitudes. This contrasts with other geographical settings where lower altitude or urban environments might use different configurations or additional remote sensing technologies.

Interpretation.Question: How do the challenges of data collection in mountainous regions affect the reliability of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges, such as the varied placement of weather stations primarily in valleys and the limited number of high-altitude stations, can impact the accuracy of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients. These factors may lead to discrepancies in the estimated values, as the data may not fully represent the diverse topography and climatic conditions of the mountainous region.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately measuring the vertical temperature gradient in mountainous regions like Sejila Mountain?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in measuring the vertical temperature gradient are influenced by several factors, including the geographical location of the meteorological stations, which are mostly situated in valley areas except for a few on the ridges like the col, treeline, and ecological stations. Additionally, the limited number of high-altitude stations, especially on the west slope, can affect the accuracy of the temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient measurements.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the variation in precipitation gradients during monsoon and non-monsoon periods in the southeastern Tibetan region?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variation in precipitation gradients during different periods is caused by changes in altitude-related precipitation patterns. During the monsoon period, precipitation first increases, then decreases, and increases again with altitude, while in the non-monsoon period, it decreases first and then increases with altitude. These changes reflect the influence of monsoonal climatic conditions on precipitation distribution.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using high-altitude meteorological stations on understanding vertical temperature gradients in mountainous regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: High-altitude meteorological stations, like those on Sejila Mountain, provide critical data for understanding vertical temperature gradients. These stations can reveal how temperature decreases with altitude, which is crucial for studying mountain ecosystems and climate patterns. However, the placement of most stations in valley areas, rather than on ridges, may affect the accuracy of the vertical temperature gradient data due to limited high-altitude coverage.

Causal Consequence.Question: How could the choice of sensor models impact the quality and reliability of meteorological data collected in high-altitude regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The choice of sensor models, such as the HMP155A for temperature and humidity or the RG3-M for rainfall, directly impacts data quality and reliability. For instance, precipitation measurements may be less accurate in winter and spring due to sensor limitations, leading to potential data deviations. These sensor characteristics can affect the accuracy of climate and ecological models that rely on such data.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of collecting meteorological data such as temperature, humidity, wind speed, and pressure at high-altitude stations like those on Mount Sejila?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to provide researchers with reliable data to study ecology, climate, hydrology, and glacial sciences, due to the unique meteorological conditions at high altitudes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to understand the vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation in mountainous regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Understanding these gradients helps in recognizing the physiological and ecological characteristics of plant and animal distributions with altitude changes, and provides reliable data for future hydrological modeling in the region.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can researchers estimate the temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient in mountainous regions using meteorological data from multiple stations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers use regression analysis of station elevation against temperature or precipitation to estimate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients. The data is collected from multiple meteorological stations, categorized by geographical units like east and west slopes based on their positions, to understand vertical changes.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods are used to measure meteorological parameters at high-altitude mountain stations?
Enablement.Answer: The data collection methods involve the use of an automatic weather station (AWS) equipped with various sensors, such as the HMP155A temperature and humidity probe, RG3-M rain gauge, PTB210 atmospheric pressure sensor, and the 05103 wind speed sensor, all mounted 2 meters above the ground.

Enablement.Question: What challenges are associated with collecting meteorological data in high-altitude regions, and how do they impact data quality?
Enablement.Answer: One of the challenges is the limitation of observational instruments in accurately measuring precipitation, particularly in winter and spring, which may lead to discrepancies between recorded and actual precipitation data. Additionally, the location of most meteorological stations in valley areas, with fewer stations on the western slope and at higher altitudes, can affect the accuracy of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients.

Enablement.Question: What resources or conditions enable the accurate estimation of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions?
Enablement.Answer: Accurate estimation is enabled by using data from multiple meteorological stations covering various elevations and aspects, such as the 11 stations located on the eastern and western slopes of the mountain. Regression analysis of station elevation against temperature or precipitation data helps estimate these gradients, taking into account geographical and seasonal variations.

Expectation.Question: What factors could affect the calculation of vertical temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions like Sejila Mountain?
Expectation.Answer: The vertical temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients can be affected by several factors, including the placement of meteorological stations in valleys rather than ridges, the limited number of high-altitude stations, and the natural variations in topography and microclimates.

Judgmental.Question: What might be some challenges in ensuring the accuracy and reliability of meteorological data collection methods used in high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in high-altitude data collection include the limited number of meteorological stations at high altitudes, potential biases in precipitation data due to monitoring limitations, and the positioning of most stations in valley areas rather than ridges, which may affect the accuracy of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how could existing meteorological datasets be expanded or refined to better support ecological and hydrological research in mountainous regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Expanding meteorological datasets could involve increasing the number of high-altitude stations, deploying more sensors at different elevations, especially on ridges, and improving the temporal resolution of data collection. Additionally, integrating data from multiple sources such as remote sensing could provide a more comprehensive picture of ecological and hydrological dynamics.

Judgmental.Question: What considerations should researchers keep in mind when selecting data collection methods for studying vertical temperature and precipitation gradients in mountainous areas?
Judgmental.Answer: Researchers should consider factors such as the geographical distribution of stations across different slopes, the sensitivity and accuracy of the instruments used, and the potential influence of local topography on microclimatic conditions. It's also important to assess how well the data collection methods capture seasonal variations and extreme weather events, which are critical for understanding vertical climate gradients.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges faced in ensuring data quality from meteorological stations located in remote high-altitude regions.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include limitations of monitoring instruments, especially in measuring precipitation accurately during winter and spring seasons. The placement of most stations in valleys rather than ridges, and the scarcity of stations on the western slope and at high altitudes, also pose challenges to data accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies for improving the accuracy of temperature and precipitation gradient estimations in mountainous regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Improving accuracy in gradient estimations can involve increasing the number of meteorological stations across different altitudes and slopes, particularly expanding coverage in high-altitude and west slope areas. Analyzing geographical factors such as station location (ridge vs. valley) and implementing regression analysis based on station elevation can also enhance gradient estimations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the potential for integrating additional datasets or data sources to enhance research on the vertical temperature and precipitation gradients in mountainous ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: Integrating data from the Linzhi Meteorological Bureau, which includes stations like Bayi, Niqi, and others, along with the main station and treeline stations of Southeast Tibet, can provide comprehensive coverage. This integration of data from multiple sources allows for a more robust analysis of temperature and precipitation gradients, offering reliable data support for ecological, hydrological, and climate studies in the region.
